original: HÄGGLUND, Erik Karl Mauritz, Professor, Stockholm, f Hässjö, Medelp, 15/6 87 av landsfiskal E Hägglund o Margreta öhlén, gm Aina Forsberg. Mog.ex Sundsvall 06, StHS 06—11, fil mag 09, fil lic 11, fil dr 14. Aman v StHS 08—11, kem v Bergviks sulfitfabr o sulfit-spritfabr 11—15, e.o. lekt i Eksjö 15—16, kem o avd.ch i Th Goldschmidt AG i Essen o Mannheim 16—20, prof i skogsprodukternas kemi o kem teknol v Åbo akad 20—30, prof i cellulosatekn o träkemi KTH fr 30, förest f cellulosaind :s centrallab fr 36. Led av Sv tekn vetensk.akad i Finl 24. Hed.dr i Heidelberg 39. LIVA 34. Styr.led Sv Tekn.frn 34—36. Norblad-Ekstrand-priset, GM 23. MitschM 38. Av trycket bl. a.: Die hydrolyse der Zellulose und des Holzes (15), Die Sulfitablauge und ihre Verar-beitung auf Alkohol (21), Nya vägar f träförsockring (24), Holschemie (3. uppl, 43), Un-tersuchungen iiber die Chemie der Sulfitzell-stoffkochung, 40 Medd (24—43), Natronzellstoff (26). RNO, KFinlVRO2kl.
translated: HÄGGLUND, Erik Karl Mauritz, Professor, Stockholm, born in Hässjö, Medelp, 15/6 1887, son of district prosecutor E Hägglund and Margreta Öhlén, married to Aina Forsberg. Graduated from Sundsvall in 1906, studied at Stockholm University 1906-1911, obtained a Bachelor's degree in 1909, a Master's degree in 1911, and a Doctorate in Philosophy in 1914. Was an assistant teacher at Stockholm University 1908-1911, worked as a chemist at Bergvik Sulphite Factory and Sulphite Alcohol Factory 1911-1915, served as a temporary lecturer in Eksjö 1915-1916, chemist and department head at Th Goldschmidt AG in Essen and Mannheim 1916-1920, professor of chemistry of forest products and chemical technology at Åbo Academy 1920-1930, professor of cellulose technology and wood chemistry at KTH from 1930, and director of the central laboratory at the Cellulose Industry from 1936. Elected member of the Finnish Academy of Technical Sciences in 1924. Honorary doctorate from Heidelberg in 1939. Member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences since 1934. Chair of the Swedish Technical Research Council from 1934-1936. Recipient of the Norblad-Ekstrand Prize in 1923. Member of the Mitscherlich Society in 1938. Published works include: "The Hydrolysis of Cellulose and Wood" (1915), "The Sulphite Solution and its Processing into Alcohol" (1921), "New Ways of Sugaring Wood" (1924), "Wood Chemistry" (3rd edition, 1943), "Investigations on the Chemistry of Sulphite Pulp Cooking" (1924-1943), "Soda Pulp" (1926). Received the Order of the North Star (RNO) and the Knight's 2nd Class of the Order of the White Rose of Finland (KFinlVRO2kl).
